title: Batch-rename files
text: folder filenames available gerp package demonstrate (’ll copy temporary folder) Confirm fs::dir_tree()
code: tmp_dir <- tempdir() tmp_files <- fs::as_fs_path(paste0(tmp_dir, "/", "filenames")) # copy fs::dir_copy(   path = system.file("filenames", package = "gerp"),    new_path = tmp_files) # confirm fs::dir_tree(tmp_dir) #> /tmp/Rtmp3TT9jn #> ├── file19932196e021 #> ├── file19936d48efee #> ├── file19937035e4da #> ├── filenames #> │   ├── JW7d^(2sl@deletethisandyourcareerisoverWx2*.txt #> │   ├── Joe's Filenames Use Space and Punctuation.xlsx #> │   ├── fig 2.png #> │   ├── figure 1.png #> │   └── myabstract.docx #> ├── rmarkdown-str199349075293.html #> └── wqy-microhei.ttc

title: Batch-rename files
text: files temporary filenames/ folder mess, want rename using standardized format. Renaming files manually can time-consuming, ’ve written handy function get 90% (pull files standardized format): file names converted lower snakecase punctuation special characters removed file names file names date prefix (birth date, options include "modification", "access", "change") ’ll demonstrate : confirm fs::dir_tree() following sections vignette walk step give better picture ger_batch_rename() works.
code: gerp::ger_batch_rename(path = tmp_files, prefix = "birth") # confirm fs::dir_tree(tmp_dir) #> /tmp/Rtmp3TT9jn #> ├── file199311bfa482 #> ├── file19932196e021 #> ├── file19933cc3cbad #> ├── file19936d48efee #> ├── file19937035e4da #> ├── filenames #> │   ├── 2023-04-07_fig-2.png #> │   ├── 2023-04-07_figure-1.png #> │   ├── 2023-04-07_joe-s-filenames-use-space-and-punctuation.xlsx #> │   ├── 2023-04-07_jw-7-d-2-sl-deletethisandyourcareerisover-wx-2.txt #> │   └── 2023-04-07_myabstract.docx #> ├── rmarkdown-str199349075293.html #> └── wqy-microhei.ttc

title: Batch-rename files
text: ’ll create another tmp_files path original (messy) file names: confirm fs::dir_tree()
code: tmp_dir <- tempdir() tmp_files <- fs::as_fs_path(paste0(tmp_dir, "/", "filenames")) # copy fs::dir_copy(   path = system.file("filenames", package = "gerp"),    new_path = tmp_files) # confirm fs::dir_tree(tmp_dir) #> /tmp/Rtmp3TT9jn #> ├── file19931d32fc87 #> └── filenames #>     ├── JW7d^(2sl@deletethisandyourcareerisoverWx2*.txt #>     ├── Joe's Filenames Use Space and Punctuation.xlsx #>     ├── fig 2.png #>     ├── figure 1.png #>     └── myabstract.docx

title: Batch-rename files
text: get_files_tbl() creates tibble file paths, names, date variables:
code: files_tmp <- get_files_tbl(path = tmp_files) glimpse(files_tmp) #> Rows: 5 #> Columns: 9 #> $ file_path      <chr> "/tmp/Rtmp3TT9jn/filenames/JW7d^(2sl@deletethisandyourc… #> $ file_folder    <chr> "/tmp/Rtmp3TT9jn/filenames", "/tmp/Rtmp3TT9jn/filenames… #> $ file_full_name <chr> "JW7d^(2sl@deletethisandyourcareerisoverWx2*.txt", "Joe… #> $ file_extension <chr> ".txt", ".xlsx", ".png", ".png", ".docx" #> $ file_name      <chr> "JW7d^(2sl@deletethisandyourcareerisoverWx2*", "Joe's F… #> $ modification   <date> 2023-04-07, 2023-04-07, 2023-04-07, 2023-04-07, 2023-04… #> $ access         <date> 2023-04-07, 2023-04-07, 2023-04-07, 2023-04-07, 2023-0… #> $ change         <date> 2023-04-07, 2023-04-07, 2023-04-07, 2023-04-07, 2023-0… #> $ birth          <date> 2023-04-07, 2023-04-07, 2023-04-07, 2023-04-07, 2023-0… files_tmp$file_full_name[1] #> [1] "JW7d^(2sl@deletethisandyourcareerisoverWx2*.txt"

title: Batch-rename files
text: Decide date use ("modification", "access", "change", "birth") date_prefix column added cleaned column names.
code: file_date_tmp <- get_date_prefix(files = files_tmp) glimpse(file_date_tmp) #> Rows: 5 #> Columns: 6 #> $ file_path      <chr> "/tmp/Rtmp3TT9jn/filenames/JW7d^(2sl@deletethisandyourc… #> $ file_folder    <chr> "/tmp/Rtmp3TT9jn/filenames", "/tmp/Rtmp3TT9jn/filenames… #> $ file_full_name <chr> "JW7d^(2sl@deletethisandyourcareerisoverWx2*.txt", "Joe… #> $ file_extension <chr> ".txt", ".xlsx", ".png", ".png", ".docx" #> $ file_name      <chr> "JW7d^(2sl@deletethisandyourcareerisoverWx2*", "Joe's F… #> $ date_prefix    <chr> "2023-04-07_", "2023-04-07_", "2023-04-07_", "2023-04-0… file_date_tmp$date_prefix[1] #> [1] "2023-04-07_"

title: Batch-rename files
text: clean_file_name formatted include date_prefix, lower-snakecase, punctuation/special characters removed. NOTE: ger_batch_rename() can’t file content file names (wouldn’t want ).
code: clean_tbl <- get_clean_file_names(file_date_tmp, file_name) glimpse(clean_tbl) #> Rows: 5 #> Columns: 4 #> $ clean_file_name <chr> "2023-04-07_jw-7-d-2-sl-deletethisandyourcareerisover-… #> $ clean_file_path <chr> "/tmp/Rtmp3TT9jn/filenames/2023-04-07_jw-7-d-2-sl-dele… #> $ file_full_name  <chr> "JW7d^(2sl@deletethisandyourcareerisoverWx2*.txt", "Jo… #> $ file_path       <chr> "/tmp/Rtmp3TT9jn/filenames/JW7d^(2sl@deletethisandyour… clean_tbl$clean_file_name[1] #> [1] "2023-04-07_jw-7-d-2-sl-deletethisandyourcareerisover-wx-2.txt" clean_tbl$file_full_name[1] #> [1] "JW7d^(2sl@deletethisandyourcareerisoverWx2*.txt"

title: Batch-rename files
text: Now place new old names vectors pass rename_all_files(): can confirm final time fs::dir_tree():
code: new_names <- clean_tbl[['clean_file_path']] old_names <- clean_tbl[['file_path']] rename_all_files(old = old_names, new = new_names) fs::dir_tree(tmp_files) #> /tmp/Rtmp3TT9jn/filenames #> ├── 2023-04-07_fig-2.png #> ├── 2023-04-07_figure-1.png #> ├── 2023-04-07_joe-s-filenames-use-space-and-punctuation.xlsx #> ├── 2023-04-07_jw-7-d-2-sl-deletethisandyourcareerisover-wx-2.txt #> └── 2023-04-07_myabstract.docx

title: Good enough code
text: Use ger_code() create R/ code folder projects:  ger_code() creates following files: can choose regular R script headers roxygen2 headers:
code: R/   ├── data.R   ├── import.R   ├── model.R   ├── tidy.R   ├── visualize.R   └── wrangle.R

title: Good enough code
text: R/data.R file used documenting datasets project. See example : create .Rd document dataset accessible Help pane.
code: #' Title (dataset description) #' #' @format A dataset with variables: #' \describe{ #'   \item{member}{Wu-Tang Clan Member Name} #'   \item{name}{Wu-Tang Clan Given Name} #'   \item{born}{Birth Year} #'   \item{city}{Birth City} #'   \item{alive}{Stil Alive?} #' } #' @source Link to data: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wu-Tang_Clan #' (downloaded YYYY-MM-DD) 'wu_df'

title: Good enough code
text: Even ’re using roxygen2 tags, ’s good idea put header code files. helps collaborators (!) track script .

title: Good enough code
text: gerp::ger_sect() create code section based name input: handy use RStudio’s outline feature:

title: create
text: two functions creating new gerp project: ger_proj() ger_create().

title: create
text: quickest way create new gerp project gerp::ger_proj(). First need install package GitHub. enter following R Console pane: ’ll see following:  New gerp project gerp::ger_proj()  New gerp projects created gerp::ger_proj() automatically place new project Desktop conspicuous location. (1)

title: create
text: ger_create() function assumes ’ve navigated project folder path quoted text string (.e, "/Users/mjfrigaard/projects/"). need help locating home R projects, check Folder paths vignette. Locate create R projects folder. can store output variable (pth) pass folder argument gerp::ger_create() (pass full path quotes).   running gerp::ger_create(), new ‘good enough’ R project open new session:  New gerp project!
code: pth <- gerp::ger_path("/Users/mjfrigaard/projects/") gerp::ger_create(   folder = pth,    name = "my project")

title: create
text: gerp projects use RStudio’s project files (extension .Rproj). .Rproj files “contain project options can also used shortcut opening project directly filesystem.”.(2)  want re-open RStudio project, navigate .Rproj file double-click open RStudio:  Opening RStudio project gerp::ger_proj() use usethis::use_course() function download zip file. ’re already using cloud platform like Dropbox Google Drive keep track files, choose different location R project folders. Cloud storage services great, ’ve known cause issues working R RStudio.

title: Good enough data
text: Use ger_data() create data folders R projects:   ger_data() creates three folders data.md file. data-raw/: contain code used import, download include data project data/: contain processed, intermediate, otherwise altered data project inst/exdata/: external data used examples testing data.md: Document data code/data.R example, stored wu_data.csv data stored inst/exdata/: code download wu_data.csv Github data-raw/wu_df.R (see ) usethis::use_data(wu_df, overwrite = TRUE) command automatically save data/ folder. ’s documented code/data.R example, can add details data.md.
code: ├── data.md ├── data ├── data-raw └── inst     └── extdata inst/extdata/         └── wu_data.csv ## code to prepare `wu_df` dataset goes here wu_df <- utils::read.csv(   "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mjfrigaard/gerp/main/inst/extdata/wu_data.csv") usethis::use_data(wu_df, overwrite = TRUE) #> ✔ Setting active project to '/home/runner/work/gerp/gerp' #> ✔ Saving 'wu_df' to 'data/wu_df.rda' #> • Document your data (see 'https://r-pkgs.org/data.html') data   └── wu_df.rda

title: Good enough documents
text: ger_dev() function creates R Markdown file development: dev/notebook.Rmd

title: Good enough documents
text: ger_report() function creates polished R Markdown file finalizing report: report/manuscript.Rmd

title: Where do I start?
text: vignette go install load gerp package, get started new gerp R project. Practice (prăk′tĭs) perform habitually customarily; make habit One first practices ’re going cover installing loading packages. R packages collection functions, data, documentation bundled standardized format. R packages vital part R ecosystem provide users wide range data analysis, visualization, modeling tools. Understanding access essential early success.

title: Where do I start?
text: R open-source programming language, anyone can create R package. packages typically shared R users online repositories like Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN) GitHub. Enter code R console download recent version gerp GitHub:

title: Where do I start?
text: gerp installed, load package using library() function

title: Where do I start?
text: ’d like get running new gerp project quickly, can enter following code RStudio Console pane (fresh RStudio session) ’ll see following:  new gerp project Windows  gerp::ger_proj() default Desktop folder (conspicuous place). ’s unlikely ’ll want project named, ‘new_project’. ’ll demonstrate change name new gerp project macOS :  Close RStudio project:  Close gerp project  Navigate new_project folder (Desktop folder) give new name:  Rename gerp project folder  ’ll also need rename .Rproj file (inside project folder)  Rename gerp project file  re-open project, navigate .Rproj file double-click open RStudio.  Rename gerp project file Good enough practices scientific computing. Wilson G, Bryan J, Cranston K, Kitzes J, Nederbragt L, et al. (2017) PLOS Computational Biology 13(6): e1005510. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1005510 Forgot Teach R. Jennifer Bryan, Jim Hester

title: Good enough names
text: “ain’t call , ’s answer .” - W.C. Fields ger_name() designed return tidyverse style name object (.e. variable). works well file names date prefix: can see, ger_name() places R object name clipboard (making easier use). ger_name() replaces following symbols abbreviations: reorganizes names start numbers: ger_name() converts just string characters something can assigned R variables. ensure names aren’t long repeat terms, ger_name() doesn’t repeat symbols.
code: ger_name("1986-10-12_file.txt") ✔ 'file_txt_1986_10_12' is copied to the clipboard! gerp::ger_name("~ ! @ # $ % ^ & * — = +") ✔ 'tilde_bang_at_num_dollar_perc_hat_and_ast_emdash_equals_plus' is copied to the clipboard! ger_name("20 % of this & that") ✔ 'perc_of_this_and_that_20' is copied to the clipboard! ger_name("123456 ! bingo + bongo") ✔ 'bang_bingo_plus_bongo_123456' is copied to the clipboard! gerp::ger_name("... !! ++") ✔ 'dot_bang_plus' is copied to the clipboard!

title: Good enough names
text: ger_fname() similar, works file names. handle’s extra white space: whatever else can come :
code: ger_fname("file.txt") ✔ '2023-03-30_file.txt' is copied to the clipboard! ger_fname("01 report .xlsx") ✔ '2023-03-30_01-report.xlsx' is copied to the clipboard! ger_fname("%! Joe's crazy *!$# file name.xlsx") ✔ '2023-03-30_joes-crazy-file-name.xlsx' is copied to the clipboard!

title: Folder paths
text: operating system folder structure refers files directories (.e. folders) organized computer’s hard drive. Folder structures can vary depending specific operating system used. However, operating systems basic design, including hierarchical tree-like arrangement similar common folders: Users/usr: user-level programs, utilities, libraries, documentation Library/lib: shared library files used applications bin: holds necessary system binary files programs etc: contains system configuration files Home/home: user-specific files directories computer’s operating system folder structure organized provide logical predictable way storing accessing folders files computer. Applications like Windows Explorer Finder present computer’s folder file structure display can navigate mouse cursor, behind scenes ’re accessing system paths (locations).

title: Folder paths
text: Folder paths typically consist series names indicate hierarchical structure folder system, separated forward slash ("/") backslash ("\") (depending operating system). Unix-based systems (like macOS Linux), topmost (root) folder usually represented forward slash (/). ’s file path, may also include file’s extension. example, Linux macOS file path might look like : usr/home/docs/file.txt system: "usr" holds user-related programs, utilities, libraries "home" user-specific files folders "docs" sub-folder within user’s home folder, "file.txt" name extension file Windows systems, root folder assigned ‘drive letter’ followed backslash (.e, C:\). example Windows file path might look like : C:\Users\Username\Documents\file.txt case: "C:" represents computer’s hard drive "Users" folder name "Username" user account folder "Documents" sub-folder within user’s home folder, "file.txt" name extension file can see two examples , file paths provide exact location file folder directory structure computer’s file system.

title: Folder paths
text: Let’s assume ’ve created projects/ folder new R projects. new projects/ folder subfolder Users folder, can locate using using Finder (macOS):  folder structure macOS  path folder :

Fortunately, RStudio helps confirm location displaying folder path Files pane folders:  Default working directory (Windows)  folder RStudio initially displays Files pane called default working directory, ’s configured install RStudio. ’d like change , can clicking Tools > Global Options Browse folder ’d like use:  Change default working directory

title: Folder paths
text: R comes helpful function printing current working directory (folder) path: getwd(). macOS, check working directory, see ’s user account folder: three functions help view computers’ folders files : dir() list.files() list.dirs() ’ll focus dir(), two work similar way.

title: Folder paths
text: Passing dir() directly console (arguments) returns list folders default working directory: add full.names = TRUE argument, see full path folders: PC, dir(full.names = TRUE) might look like : Adding full.names returned folders working directory added ./ prefix. computer file systems, "." ".." special directories (.e., folders) specific meanings. "." represents current folder ".." represents parent folder file path directory names used specify relative paths files directories file system.
code: dir()  [1] "Applications"          [2] "Creative Cloud Files"  [3] "Desktop"               [4] "Documents"             [5] "Downloads"             [6] "Dropbox"               [7] "Fonts"   [15] "Themes" dir(full.names = TRUE)  [1] "./Applications"          [2] "./Creative Cloud Files"  [3] "./Desktop"               [4] "./Documents"             [5] "./Downloads"             [6] "./Dropbox"               [7] "./Fonts"                 [8] "./Library"               [9] "./Movies"               [10] "./Music"                [11] "./Pictures"             [12] "./projects" Data"                                                     [3] "./Contacts"                                                             [4] "./Cookies" "./NetHood"                                                              [16] "./NTUSER.DAT"                                                          [17] "./OneDrive" title: Folder paths
text: Folder tree’s text displays computer’s folder structure. noted , operating systems organize folders files hierarchical, tree-like arrangement, single root folder (directory) top, sub-folders branching . folder can contain files additional subfolders , turn, can files subfolders.   ’ll use folder trees describe special directories implied "." "..":  "." represents current folder user currently . example, folder "/user/jdoe/documents", folder tree look like : case, "." refers location ("/user/jdoe/documents") ".." (dot dot) represents parent folder. .. used refer folder contains current folder. example, folder "/user/jdoe/documents" ".." refers "/user/jdoe"
code: root/   └── folder/         └── subfolder/ users/   └── jdoe/         └── documents/ <- my location users/   └── jdoe/         └── documents/ -> "." also my location users/   └── jdoe/         └── documents/ <- my location users/   └── jdoe/ -> ".." parent folder         └── documents/

title: Folder paths
text: first gerp function ’ll cover designed help become familiar folder paths: ger_path(). ’ve already installed loaded gerp package, sometimes handy explicitly tell R function intend use package. can entering package::function(), can see image :  functions objects gerp  Using package::function() shows us functions objects package. select package item, can see documentation yellow:  help ger_path()  use ger_path(), start entering forward slash enclosed quotes ("/") hit Tab key, ’ll see list folders available starting home directory.  Home directory (macOS)  can continue using mouse (arrow keys) navigate parent folder want R project live (case, ’s /Users/mjfrigaard/projects/)    ger_path() works way Windows:

title: Folder paths
text: type argument controls whether gerp::ger_path() returns relative absolute folder path. absolute path returns complete specific location folder file system, starting root directory. relative path refers location folder relative current working folder (.e., folder user currently located).

title: Folder paths
text: ’d like see folder tree path gerp::ger_path(), can set tree TRUE name package comes excellent article, ‘Good enough practices scientific computing’ Greg Wilson, Jennifer Bryan, Karen Cranston, Justin Kitzes, Lex Nederbragt Tracy K. Teal Jenny Bryan Jim Hester address many topics ‘forgot teach R’, ’ve codified package wherever .
code: gerp::ger_path("/Users/mjfrigaard/projects/", tree = TRUE) /Users/mjfrigaard/projects ├── apps ├── blogs ├── dev ├── methods └── pkgs

title: gerp 1.1.0
text: added ger_name() function creating R object names (vignette) added hex sticker package

title: gerp 1.0.0
text: New vignettes (getting-started, setup, code, data, documentation, batch-rename) Function changes make align R package development: New ger_proj(): Uses functions usethis create R project New ger_code(): Create R/ folder (instead code/) New ger_data(): Creates data-raw/, data/, inst/extdata/ ger_docs() replaced ger_dev() ger_report() ger_dev() creates dev/ folder adds R Markdown notebook ger_report() creates report/ folder adds R Markdown manuscript file ger_setup() adds changelog.md, LICENSE, CITATION requirements.md files

title: gerp 0.1.0
text: Added ger_proj(), ger_code(), ger_data(), ger_docs(), ger_setup() Added data-raw/wu_df.R, data-raw/wu_dt.R, data-raw/wu_tbl.R Added inst/extdata/wu_data.csv Added inst/rmarkdown/templates/gerp-README/README.Rmd README.Rmd template Updated README Added vignette/getting-started.Rmd Added NEWS.md file track changes package
